Summary of initial incident and investigation:
On Saturday, 10/07/2023 Bowie State University (BSU) continued a week-long series of celebrations and events as part of their annual homecoming.  Specifically, on 10/07/2023 and into 10/08/2023 BSU held their homecoming football game with additionally scheduled post-game events and celebration.


At the request of BSU, the Maryland State Police (MSP) assigned a contingent of uniformed Troopers as supplemental security to BSU Officers during post-game events and celebrations.  The MSP detail was to begin at 1900 hours on 10/07/2023 and conclude at 0300 hours on 10/08/2023.  The primary focus of MSP during this detail was to provide and increased law enforcement presence and added security through motorized and foot patrols.  I (Detective Sergeant W. Heath, assigned to the MSP - College Park Barrack) was assigned as the MSP Officer-In-Charge of the MSP detail.  In addition to myself, the following Troopers were also assigned to this detail:
Tpr. C. Barnhart – College Park Barrack
Tpr. J. Albaugh  - College Park Barrack
Tpr. N. Norman – Rockville Barrack
Tpr. G. Hershberger – Rockville Barrack
Tpr. Z. Shai – Forestville Barrack
Tpr. B. Thienhom – Forestville Barrack
TFC. B. Strong – Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division
TFC M. Moorman - Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division


In addition to MSP, BSU Police detailed 8-10 BSU police officers (to include the BSU Chief of Police who was on-location), 6 BSU security guards, and 25 private security guards to the events on 10/07/2023 – 10/08/2023.  In total, 17-19 law enforcement officers and 31 security guards were assigned to the campus.


Upon arrival to the aforementioned detail I learned, in addition to BSU students, alumni, and outside guests, students from Morgan State University in Baltimore, MD had also been invited to the homecoming events held on 10/07/2023 – 10/08/2023.  This was done in response to the cancellation of Morgan State University homecoming events as result of an (unrelated) on-campus shooting incident on 10/03/2023 in Baltimore.  Due, in-part, to the additional attendees it was apparent the number of on-campus guests and students far exceeded the number anticipated by BSU during initial planning.  Upon the arrival of myself and other Troopers, on-campus events and celebrations were already underway with additional planned throughout the evening / night.  A large crowd was already present on-campus which continued to grow in size throughout the evening.


As additional people continued to enter the campus, it was requested by BSU Police that a portion of the MSP contingent respond to two locations in effort to prevent further vehicular and foot traffic from entering.  Two Troopers were directed to the main campus entry at Jericho Park Road (north of Rt. 197) and Henry Way, while an additional two Troopers were directed to an additional entry point at Jericho Park Road and Loop Road.  Remaining Troopers provided both motorized and foot patrols of the campus.


At approximately 2235 hours I was contacted by BSU Police who advised, at the direction of the Chief, they would be terminating all events and activities at midnight.  As result, they would be requesting all guests (non-students) and unauthorized people to exit the campus.  This was in response to the large number of campus attendees.  I notified all MSP personnel of the decision and requested that each respond to the staging location, in Lot H, at 2345 hours so a coordinated effort could be made by MSP and BSU Police.  Additionally, I requested additional assistance of College Park Troopers not assigned to the BSU detail. 


At approximately 2330 hours I was contacted via MSP radio that Troopers in the area of the BSU main entrance at Jericho Park Road and Henry Way heard several gunshots and observed several people fleeing from the area on foot.  I was stationed in the Lot H staging location at that time.  Moments later I was advised Troopers encountered two subjects suffering obvious gunshot wounds.  One gunshot victim (later identified as Johnel Gray) was located along Henry Way south of Henry Circle in the area of the Entrepreneurship Living and Learning Center.  Gray had suffered a gunshot wound to his chest/shoulder area.  An additional gunshot victim (later identified as Terrence Franklin) was located in along Henry Circle, in the area of the Center for Business and Graduate Studies, and had suffered a gunshot to his hip / thigh area.  Troopers immediately requested the assistance of medics and provided medical care until the arrival of EMS.  Prince George’s County Fire / EMS later transported each victim to the Capital Regional Medical Center for emergency medical treatment.  Gray was transported via ambulance #818 (run number 23100700000487) and Franklin was transported via ambulance #819 (run number 23100700000482).


While responding to and treating Franklin, Troopers located a Glock handgun lying on the ground in close proximity to his location.  The firearm was recovered and made safe by Tpr. Barnhart.  It was held as evidence pending follow-up investigation.  Shortly thereafter a preliminary crime scene was located by Troopers along Henry Circle spanning through Henry Way north of Jericho Park Road.  The crime scene consisted of various clothing items, blood evidence, and a number of spent shell casings all consistent with a shooting scene.  Troopers secured the crime scene location and preserved physical evidence in its original location for follow-up investigation and processing.


Upon first being notified of the shooting I immediately made contact with BSU Police and advised them of the two confirmed gunshot victims and updated them of the preliminary location of the shooting incident.  At that time Tpr. Albaugh and Tpr. Norman had arrived at the staging location and were present with me.  Several people, who had heard the gunshots, had begun to flee the Holmes Plaza area on foot.  This was the primary location for the evening’s events and was the most populated area at the time.  Although several people had begun to flee on foot, several hundred people were still present in the Holmes Plaza.  At that time Tpr. Albaugh, Tpr. Norman, and I entered the Holmes Plaza to begin clearing people from the area.  While making our way through the Holmes Plaza we began walking toward a large crowd of people still congregating in the area of the Holmes Hall and Kennard Hall.  While approaching the area, Tpr. Albaugh, Tpr. Norman, and I heard an additional 2-3 gunshots which sounded to be in relative close proximity to us.  The gunshots sounded to originate in the area in which we were traveling on foot.  The area could best be identified as an area between the Henry Wise Wellness Center and Center for Sciences, Mathematics, and Nursing (south of Holmes and Kennard Halls).  Immediately upon hearing the gunshots several people who were congregated in the crowd began fleeing the area on foot.  Tpr. Albaugh, Tpr. Norman, and I raced to the area in effort to locate a shooter and canvas the area for potential victims.  There were no apparent suspects or victims in the area. 


It should be noted that later during follow-up investigation, I was provided surveillance video of two shooting suspects at the original shooting location.  During a review of the video I observed two suspects firing handguns.  One suspect appeared to be a black male, appearing to be early-mid 20’s, thin to medium build, with shorter-style hair.  He was wearing black pants, white sneakers, a white shirt, and black jacket.  He was last observed fleeing on foot in the direction of Loop Road after firing from a handgun on Henry Circle.  An additional suspect appeared to be a black male, believed to be early-mid 20’s, thin to medium build, with medium-length dreadlock or braided style hair.  He was wearing light colored pants, white shoes, and a white hooded sweatshirt.  This suspect was observed fleeing on foot in the direction of Henry Way after firing from a handgun in the area of Henry Circle and Henry Way.  Later in the video this same suspect (dressed in the white hooded sweatshirt) is observed returning to the area and firing additional rounds from a handgun, after some time had passed following the initial shooting report.  It is possible, after having reviewed the video footage, the second set of gunshots Tpr. Albaough, Tpr. Norman, and I heard may have likely come from this same suspect when he returned to fire additional rounds. 


Several minutes following the second set of gunshots, I was advised by BSU Police that additional gunshots were reportedly heard in the area of the on-campus MARC Penn Line parking lot.  I immediately directed Troopers to respond to the area in effort to locate shooting suspects, victims, or evidence of a shooting scene.  Responding Troopers were unable to locate suspects, victims, or evidence supporting an additional shooting had taken place.


Following the aforementioned events I requested additional MSP resources to include an additional patrol response from neighboring Barracks, activation of the Mobile Field Force, and response from Special Operations Division personnel.  Prince George’s County Police Department aviation was requested and responded to provide aerial support.  Each of those resources later responded in support of the detail.


Additionally I made contact with the BSU Chief of Police and Prince George’s County Police and established a unified command post in Lot H.  BSU Police, Prince George’s County Police, MSP, and Prince George’s County Fire / EMS Officers-In-Charge maintained the unified command post until the arrival of additional resources.  Upon the arrival of MSP Special Operations Division they also joined the unified command post.  On-scene follow-up operational (non-investigative) assignments were distributed to supporting personnel through the command post.  Throughout I provided command notifications to MSP commissioned ranks to ensure updated information was available for their use as necessary.


I made contact with the MSP – Criminal Enforcement Division and advised them of the incident.  I requested investigators respond to the location to assume primary investigation.  Several members of the Criminal Enforcement Division responded to the scene while additional investigators were directed to the Capital Regional Medical Center to make contact with victims Gray and Franklin.  I remained on-scene to assist investigators and coordinate additional patrol functions as needed.


While still on-scene I was contacted by the Forestville Barrack who advised they had stopped to assist a vehicle in the area of Central Avenue following the shooting.  During contact with the occupants of that vehicle, the Trooper identified the occupants as Khalil Vassell and Norris Vassell.  During contact with them the Trooper located two Glock 19 handguns, one upon the person of Khalil and a second in the common area of the vehicle.  The Vassell’s indicated they had been at BSU earlier in the evening.  As result, a Criminal Enforcement Division investigators responded to the scene and took custody of the two Glock handguns for further investigation.  They were transported to and stored at the College Park Barrack.


On 10/12/2023 I successfully completed a test fire of each Glock handgun which confirmed both to be operational and capable of being fired.  I am certified through the Maryland State Police to operate and test fire with the Operation Test Shot system stored within the College Park Barrack property room.  Two projectiles and two shell casings from each firearm were collected from the Operation Test Shot system and were turned over to Sgt. Whitmore, who witnessed the successful test fires.  On 10/13/2023 Sgt. Whitmore transported the projectiles and shell casings to the MSP – Forensic Sciences Division for analysis and entry into NIBIN.  The firearms remain stored in the College Park Property room, along with the handgun recovered from BSU which was turned over from Sgt. Whitmore.


I am currently working to obtain radios transmissions from the College Park Barrack related to the BSU detail and shooting incident which, once available, will be provided to Sgt. Whitmore.


I will remain available to assist the Criminal Enforcement Division as necessary and additional supplemental reports will be completed as necessary.


This case remains open pending further investigation.

On Tuesday, 10-10-2023, investigators requested copies of any/all 9-1-1 calls related to the incident.  Investigators await the Prince George’s County 9-1-1 Center's response.  Investigators will contact them again on Wednesday, 10-11-2023 in hopes of reviewing any/all 9-1-1 calls in hopes it generates some investigative leads.  

  On Tuesday, 10-10-2023, investigators contacted the Bowie City Police Department regarding 9-1-1 calls and learned that all calls are routed through the PG County 9-1-1 center.  On Wednesday, 10-11-2023, Cpl. Posey of MSP CED Central South Region will contact Bowie City Police Department to obtain any/all calls for service on the roadways/neighborhoods that border BSU in hopes it generates some investigative leads.

   On Wednesday, 10-11-2023, Cpl. Posey-(MSP Central South Region) contacted Prince George's County's 911 call center to get a timeframe on compliance with the audio request. Cpl. Posey spoke with Ulrica Lee at 301-352-1401 who stated the request was received, but she could not advise on a timeline. She stated it takes about thirty days. Cpl. Posey asked if there was a way to expedite the process? Cpl. Posey was put on hold for her to consult her supervisor. Cpl. Posey was told the department was short staffed and it would more than likely take thirty days. It was then stated, once the audio is copied it has to go through the Office Of Law before being released to the Maryland State Police and they do not control how long the Office Of Law takes. Cpl. Posey requested to come down and listen to whatever calls they may have in person. Cpl. Posey was put on hold and transferred to an audio technician who provided most of the same information but also suggested he get a copy of the Prince George's County Police Department’s CAD card in the meantime. Cpl. Posey was able to obtain information for two different Prince George’s County officers, one of which was Deputy Chief O’leary. Deputy Chief O’leary was given the information requested and is attempting to help expedite the process and obtain the information needed to assist this investigation. Cpl. Posey contacted the Bowie City Police via email. Sgt. Howard of Bowie City’s investigative unit was sent an email requesting any and all emergency or non-emergency calls for service close to Bowie State University or surrounding areas.

  On October 20, 2023 at approximately 1300 hours, Cpl. Posey and Sgt. Newcomer responded to 17321 Melford Blvd., Bowie Maryland to Prince George's County 911 call center to listen to all emergency call. Numerous calls were heard from Bowie State University to the 911 center and additional 911 calls from the surrounding areas. Various phone numbers and names were obtained to follow-up on the information provided to the 911 center.

  Cpl Posey contacted one of the 911 callers at 347-399-8272 Cpl. Posey contacted the number listed and got an answer. Cpl. Posey stated who he was and why he was calling. Without any questions asked, the call taker (unnamed at this point) stated she arrived in the area of Bowie State University after the shooting to meet up with friends. She stated she took a wrong turn and her vehicle ended up stuck on a rail trail. She stated she called the police an nobody helped her. Cpl. Posey asked her name and she stated Shayne Stevens. Cpl. Posey asked Ms. Stevens to meet to record her statement to potentially get more details and further the investigation? Stevens adamantly refused stating she wasn't involved in the shooting, she showed up after, and the police did not help her so she'll probably never call the police again. Cpl. Posey reassured her that we are not the department she called and would love to sit and speak to her about her incident in detail. Stevens stated she did not have time she's a college student and would not get involved. Cpl. Posey asked her to please reach out if she hears anything regarding the shooting from other students. 

  Cpl. Posey made several attempts to contact Harley Holmes 301-892-1734. Ms. Holmes has not responded to any of Cpl. Posey's calls, voicemails, or text. Cpl. Posey responded to the 7 Eleven on  7404 Laurel - Bowie Rd, Bowie, MD 20715. Cpl. Posey made contact with the manager and was able to obtain video from the 7 Eleven displaying the accident that Holmes reported. Cpl. Posey reached out to Prince George's County Det. Denise Shapiro in an attempt to get further information for Holmes. Cpl. Posey has not heard anything back as of yet.

  On 11/16/2023 at approximately 1033 hours, Harley Holmes contacted Cpl. Posey by phone. Cpl. Posey discussed the reason for the call to Holmes and Holmes agreed to meet Cpl. Posey for a recorded interview in the future. Due to Holmes class schedule and the Holiday no interview has been conducted.

*BWC was NOT activated for this interaction*

Focus: The focus of this supplement is to document an interview with Jones-Peoples

Witness:
  • Jones-Peoples, Kyle Anthony
    • B/M DOB: 04/12/1995
Narrative:
    On October 19, 2023, I, Cpl Z. Null 6149 of the Maryland State Police Criminal Enforcement Division, was reviewing open forum social media posts in an attempt to identify possible leads and/or witnesses. While doing so, I noted a Twitter post by username “Thatmanpeanut” that was suitable for follow up.

    On October 8, 2023, Thatmanpeanut retweeted a news post about the shooting on October 7, 2023, at Bowie State University with the caption "SMH". On October 8, 2023, Thatmanpeanut subsequently made a post stating, "That shooting happened in front of me smh glad I made it home safe. Dude emptied the clip." Through investigative efforts utilizing Law Enforcement and Public Databases, I was able to identify the account owner as Jones-Peoples, Kyle Anthony (B/M DOB: 04/12/1995).

    On October 19, 2023, I was able to make contact with Jones-Peoples via telephone and conducted an interview. Jones-Peoples advised he was walking south on Henry Cir when he heard the shots. He described numerous shots being fired. Jones-Peoples advised he fled between buildings in the general direction of the train station. When asked, Jones-Peoples stated he did not hear any confrontation or fighting before the fight, therefore, he was not able to get a description of any suspects or persons of interest. Jones-Peoples did not have much information to pass along because he stated he was in fear for his life so he just ran away. Jones-People was very cooperative, he just did not seem to have information that could aide the investigation.

    Jones-Peoples advised he was in a black crew neck long sleeved shirt, black pants, and possible vans when the shooting occurred.

    Contact information was provided to Jones-Peoples, and he advised he would be available for additional interviews should the need arise.

INVESTIGATOR: Sergeant B. Whitmore #6094
UNIT: Criminal Enforcement Division - Central South Region
DATE ASSIGNED: 10/07/2023
CASE STATUS: Open
FOCUS: This report captures 9-1-1 caller interviews for individuals who made calls in reference to the shooting investigation.

BWC activated 

Chassidy Hernandez DOB 11/22/2001
Phone # 240-602-9385

On 10-24-2023 at approximately 1525 hours I made contact with 9-1-1 caller, Chassidy Hernandez, at the Bowie State University Campus.  Hernandez advised she was on campus during the homecoming event in proximity to Lot H on the campus. She advised she heard the sounds of gunshots and fled the area. She stated she attempted to enter a building but was denied entry by campus staff / security personnel.  Hernandez then called 911 and reported this to the emergency communication dispatcher. Hernandez advised she wasn't anywhere near the contact shooting location and would not be able to provide details on possible suspects.  She was advised to contact investigators if she learned of anything to assist the investigation.  
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Interview recorded audibly

Chaedon Rosemond
Phone # 860-814-2567

On 10-25-2023 at approximately 1518 hours I made contact with 9-1-1 Chadeon Rosemond in Towson, MD. Rosemond advised he is a student at Morgan State University, and he was on campus during the homecoming event on Henry Circle when he heard multiple sets of gunshots. He believed there were multiple shooters and heard the sounds of projectiles hitting trees in the area. I showed Rosemond a map of Henry Circle and asked him to explain where he was in relation to the shooting. He explained he was on the opposite side and ran in the opposite direction towards the computer science building.  He was unable to provide any suspect descriptions. Rosemond was advised to contact investigators if he learned of anything to assist the investigation.  
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
BWC activated

Jeffrey Wright DOB 07/15/1965
Phone# 443-953-9159

On 10-26-2023 at approximately 1405 hours I made contact with Jeffrey Wright at the Community College of Baltimore County - Catonsville. Wright is a Bowie State University Alumni and was attending the event with friends and former fraternity brothers. Wright showed me his location on a map and it was in the area of Holmes Plaza. He was not in proximity to the shooting and was unable to provide any suspect descriptions. Wright was advised to contact investigators if he learned of anything to assist the investigation.  

Case open

INVESTIGATOR: Sergeant B. Whitmore #6094
UNIT: Criminal Enforcement Division - Central South Region
DATE ASSIGNED: 10/07/2023
CASE STATUS: Open
FOCUS: This report captures investigative efforts in reference to DNA testing and latent fingerprint processing. The report also contains the crime scene report completed by the Crime Scene Technician and the Latent Print Report.

ATTACHMENTS:
-Crime Scene Report
-Crime Scene Notes and Sketches
-360 Photographs of Scene (stored on disc separate from report)
-Latent Print Report

MSP – Forensic Sciences Division was contacted on Thursday, 10-26-2023 regarding the possibility of testing the spent shell casings for touch DNA and for latent prints.  Following a request to the Director, Biology advised they would conduct the DNA tests but also advised the success rates of these tests are very minimal. Biology also advised this type of testing is outsourced to BODE labs and latent lift attempts will need to be processed first. Latent Print advised the process could be completed by Friday 11-3-2023; However, if they recovered prints from the casings the process could be extended due to the prints needing to be analyzed and compared. 

On 12-11-2023 Sgt Whitmore received the Latent Print report in reference to the shell casings recovered. The analysis revealed there are no latent print impressions suitable for identification purposes. 

On 12-13-2023, Sgt Whitmore responded to MSP Crime Lab to retrieve the casings and sent them via Fedex to BODE Lab for subsequent DNA testing. Testing should be completed in approximately 60 days.

CASE OPEN

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeTitle: Search Warrants - Tower Dump, Instagram, T-Mobile
IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
INVESTIGATOR: Sergeant B. Whitmore #6094
UNIT: Criminal Enforcement Division - Central South Region
DATE ASSIGNED: 10/07/2023
CASE STATUS: Open
FOCUS: This report captures investigative efforts involving the suspect's social media and cell carrier information.

ATTACHMENTS:
-Tower Dump Data (large file - retained externally)
-Lyft subpoena return
-Instagram Warrant
-T-Mobile Warrant
-Tower Dump Warrant
-T-Mobile Data (202) 321-2879 (large file - retained externally)
-Instagram return (large file - retained externally)


Lyft subpoena results were returned on Tuesday, 10-24-2023. No actionable leads were generated from these results.  Only one user made a ride request in the area described in the crime solvers tip.  The customer was dropped off in Northwest DC and not in Prince George’s County. Three other accounts with the name “Jebbrel” were located by Lyft in the region but none of the users received a ride during the time frame in question.

On Tuesday, 10-31-2023, after Prince George’s County State's Attorney’s Office approval was received, Sgt Whitmore submitted a search warrant for tower records to Prince George’s County Circuit Court Judge Stenise Rolle. The warrant was later signed and authorized during the evening hours of 10-31. Sgt Whitmore served the warrant to Verizon, T-Mobile and AT&T on 11-1-2023.

T-Mobile provided tower records to Sergeant Whitmore on November 9, 2023.  Sgt Whitmore conducted a search of the records and located Metts’s known phone number (202) 321-2879 44 instances from 2322 hours to 2338 hours.  It should be noted again that the shooting occurred on surveillance footage at 2332 hours.  This phone was active on tower data consistently up until 2338 hours.  It was also active at 2331 hours with the next activation at 2333 hours, approximately one minute after the shooting. The phone was not active during the shooting.
 
AT&T provided their tower records on 11-15-2023 and Verizon provided theirs on 11-28-2023. 

The phone number (202) 321-2879 was obtained by allied law enforcement agencies who are also investigating Metts for separate crimes and he is known by multiple agencies to utilize this number.  A subpoena was previously sent to T-Mobile for subscriber information and revealed the subscriber was listed as “Jake Baker” with an address of 3335 7th Street SE Washington DC 20032.  The last known address for Metts is also 3335 7th Street SE Washington DC 20032. It is an active number with an activation date of 03/08/2020.

The following phone numbers were in contact with Metts's known number during times of 2322 hours - 2342 hours

301-367-1859
202-704-1242
240-940-7199
202-302-6930
202-903-7551
301-836-8208

Each number was subpoenaed for subscriber information and call detail records (CDRs). They were sent to their respective carriers on 11-20-2023.

Sgt Whitmore completed a search and seizure warrant for Metts known Instagram again after learning his phone was present in the area during the shooting and an additional warrant was authored for his known T-Mobile phone number. These warrants were sent for review to a Prince George’s County Circuit Court Judge on 11-21-2023 and were subsequently signed.  Each warrant was sent to their respective company on the afternoon of 11-21-2023.

On 11-30-2023 Sgt Whitmore received the returns from both Meta and T-Mobile. Both accounts were thoroughly reviewed but revealed no admission of “Foot” being involved in the shooting on the campus. Upon review of data received from Metts’s Instagram, several direct messages to Metts were located which other individuals addressed him as “Foot”. Another user messaged Metts and asked “You fumbled ur stick moe?”. This message was sent approximately two hours after the shooting occurred and investigators know from previous investigations that “stick” is often a slang term for a firearm.

Investigators also submitted a request to Apple to determine if “Metts's” phone number has an iCloud account associated with it. Apple replied that the number corresponded to an iPhone, so investigators authored a warrant for his iCloud account. 

On 12-15-2023 Sgt Whitmore submitted the warrant to Prince George’s County Circuit Judge Coderre for review, following approval from the State’s Attorney’s Office. The warrant was signed and submitted to Apple. 

Investigators are in the process of reviewing T-Mobile data; however, at this time it appears no SMS messages were retained or provided by the carrier.

CASE OPEN
